text: Before we start the story, let me remind
you why stories are the best way to
learn English. When you listen to or
read stories, you learn new words, see
how sentences are formed, and understand
how people speak in real life. Plus,
stories are interesting. You don't feel
like you're studying, but at the same
time, you're learning a lot. Today,
we're going to explore Joker 2019. I'm
going to tell you everything about the
movie, including every small detail.
This will help you understand English
better, and you'll also enjoy an amazing
story. The movie was deep, emotional,
and full of twists. So, get ready. The
beginning of the story revolves around
Arthur Fleck. The movie starts in Gotham
City, a dark, grim place where crime and
poverty are at an all-time high. Gotham
is almost like a character itself,
setting the tone for everything that
happens. The streets are dirty, people
are angry, and there's a huge gap
between the rich and the poor. This city
is not just a backdrop. It plays a
crucial role in shaping the characters,
especially our main character, Arthur
Fleck. Arthur is a lonely, struggling
man who works as a clown. His job is to
dress up in clown makeup and entertain
people at places like children's
hospitals, stores, and parties. However,
his life is anything but joyful. He
lives with his sick mother, Penny Fleck,
in a small, run-down apartment. His
mother believes Arthur is destined for
greatness. But Arthur doesn't feel that
way. Arthur suffers from mental health
problems, one of which is a condition
that makes him laugh uncontrollably at
inappropriate times. This laughter isn't
out of happiness. It's a nervous
reaction he can't control. He even
carries a small card explaining his
condition to people when they get
confused or uncomfortable. Every day,
Arthur tries to make people happy, but
no one seems to care about him. He's
ignored, mocked, and treated badly by
society. Gotham City reflects Arthur's
internal struggle. Dirty, broken, and
full of anger. Arthur has a dream of
becoming a stand-up comedian. He
believes that if he can make people
laugh, maybe they'll finally notice him
and love him. He idolizes Murray
Franklin, a famous talk show host, and
watches his show every night. In his
imagination, he sees himself being
invited on the show and praised by
Murray like a father figure. But
Arthur's reality is far from this dream.
He's terrible at stand-up comedy. When
he performs, people either don't laugh
or laugh at him, not with him. He writes
jokes and thoughts in a notebook, but
his material is awkward and
uncomfortable, much like Arthur himself.
One day, while Arthur is working as a
clown holding a sign outside a store,
some teenagers steal his sign and run
away. When Arthur chases them, they beat
him badly in an alleyway. This
heartbreaking scene shows how Arthur is
constantly bullied and mistreated by the
world. Arthur's coworker, Randall, gives
him a gun for protection. This becomes a
turning point because Arthur was
defenseless before, but now things begin
to change for better or worse. At home,
Arthur's life is just as difficult. He
takes care of his sick mother who
believes Thomas Wayne will help them.
Arthur is tired and burdened by
responsibility while his own life falls
apart. They live in poverty, barely
making ends meet. Arthur also visits a
social worker, but the system fails him.
When funding is cut, he loses access to
therapy and medication. This shows how
society repeatedly fails people like
Arthur. The most important turning point
happens on a subway train. Arthur, still
in his clown outfit, sees three rich,
drunk men harassing a woman. He begins
laughing uncontrollably due to his
condition. and the men attack him. In
desperation, Arthur pulls out the gun
and kills them. For the first time,
Arthur fights back. He feels power. But
this violent act changes everything for
Arthur and Gotham. The city reacts with
chaos. People idolize the clown killer
as a symbol of rebellion against the
rich and corrupt. Clown masks appear,
protests fill the streets, and tension
explodes.
Arthur begins to feel liberated. The
killings give him control and attention.
This is when he starts embracing his
identity as the Joker. Arthur later
discovers the truth about his past. His
mother lied about Thomas Wayne being his
father. Hospital records reveal Arthur
was adopted and abused as a child. This
discovery completely shatters him.
Arthur is invited onto the Murray
Franklin show after his failed comedy
routine is mocked on TV. He sees this as
revenge. On live television, he admits
to the subway murders and shoots Murray.
This moment fully transforms Arthur into
the Joker. Gotham erupts into fullscale
riots. Arthur is freed by rioters and
lifted onto a crashed police car. In an
iconic scene, he dances triumphantly as
the crowd cheers. In the final scene,
Arthur is in Arkham State Hospital.
Laughing to himself, he tells the
therapist, "You wouldn't get it." He
walks away, leaving bloody footprints
behind. The ending is ambiguous. Has he
escaped or is he trapped in endless
madness? After the subway incident,
Arthur Fleck is no longer the same
person. The fear he once felt slowly
turns into confidence. For the first
time in his life, he feels noticed.
Gotham City begins to change as well.
News channels talk nonstop about the
three rich men who were killed on the
subway. They describe the killer as a
clown and this image spreads across the
city. Poor and angry people start seeing
the clown as a symbol of protest against
the rich and corrupt. Arthur follows the
news closely. At first he is scared of
getting caught, but slowly he starts to
enjoy the attention. Even though no one
knows his name, the city is finally
reacting because of him. At work,
Arthur's life becomes worse. His boss
fires him after learning about the gun
incident. Arthur tries to explain, but
no one listens. Once again, society
rejects him without understanding the
full story. At home, Arthur's
relationship with his mother begins to
break. Penny keeps writing letters to
Thomas Wayne, believing he will help
them. Arthur becomes curious and decides
to read one of the letters. In the
letter, Penny claims Thomas Wayne is
Arthur's father. This shocks Arthur
deeply. Confused and angry, he starts
questioning everything about his life.
He decides to find the truth himself.
Arthur goes to Wayne Manor and meets
young Bruce Wayne. For a brief moment,
Arthur feels a strange connection. But
when Thomas Wayne confronts him later,
he cruy denies everything. He tells
Arthur that Penny is mentally ill and
that Arthur was adopted. Arthur refuses
to believe it at first, but when he
steals hospital records, the truth
becomes clear. Penny lied to him for
years. Arthur was abused as a child and
his mental condition came from that
trauma. This revelation destroys Arthur
emotionally. The last source of comfort
in his life disappears. Feeling
betrayed, lost, and empty, Arthur
finally snaps. He stops taking his
medication. He stops trying to fit into
society. Instead, he begins to accept
the chaos inside him. Arthur fully
transforms into the Joker. He dyes his
hair green, paints his face, and wears a
bright red suit. This new appearance
reflects his new identity. Bold,
fearless, and dangerous. Meanwhile,
Gotham is burning. Clown masked
protesters fill the streets, violence
spreads everywhere, and the rich lose
control. Arthur is invited to the Murray
Franklin show. For years, Murray was his
hero. Now Arthur sees him as part of the
cruel system that mocked and ignored
him. On live television, Arthur
confesses to the subway killings. He
speaks about society's hypocrisy and
cruelty. Then, in a shocking moment, he
kills Murray on air. This act pushes
Gotham into complete chaos. Riots
explode across the city. Arthur becomes
a symbol of rebellion. whether he
intended to or not. As he is taken away
by police, rioters rescue him. They lift
him onto a car, cheering and
celebrating. Arthur dances, smiling
through blood and madness. For the first
time in his life, Arthur Fleck feels
truly seen. The lonely man is gone. Only
the Joker remains.
After Arthur becomes the Joker, his life
reaches a point of no return. Gotham
City is now completely out of control.
The streets are filled with fire, anger,
and violence. People wearing clown masks
riot everywhere, destroying buildings
and attacking the rich. Arthur is taken
to Arkham State Hospital, a psychiatric
institution. Here the movie shows us the
final stage of his transformation. He is
no longer confused or afraid. Instead,
he looks calm, confident, and detached
from reality. A therapist sits across
from him and asks simple questions.
Arthur laughs quietly to himself. When
she asks, "What is so funny?" he
replies, "You wouldn't get it." This
line is very important. It shows that
Arthur believes no one can ever
understand his pain, his past, or his
transformation.
Society failed him so many times that he
is completely given up on being
understood. Arthur then walks through
the hospital hallway. As he moves
forward, we see bloody footprints behind
him. The movie does not clearly show
what happened, leaving the ending open.
Did Arthur kill the therapist or is the
blood only a symbol of the violence
inside his mind? This uncertainty makes
the ending powerful and disturbing. It
reminds us that the Joker is not just a
man but an idea. Chaos, anger, and
rebellion. Arthur's story forces us to
think deeply. Was he born a monster or
was he created by society? The film
suggests that neglect, cruelty, and lack
of care can push a broken person into
madness. Mental illness is one of the
film's strongest themes. Arthur asks for
help many times, but no one listens. The
health care system cuts funding. People
laugh at him instead of showing empathy.
The movie also highlights the gap
between the rich and the poor. While the
wealthy live comfortably, the poor
suffer silently. Arthur becomes a symbol
for those who feel ignored and
powerless. By the end of the story,
Arthur Fleck no longer exists. The Joker
has taken his place completely. He is no
longer trying to be loved. He no longer
wants approval. All he wants now is to
be seen. And the world is finally
watching. This is why Joker 2019 is not
just a movie. It is a warning. It shows
what can happen when society turns its
back on the most vulnerable
